subject: introduction to JUNIT for beginner  (pls let me have a feed back)
msgSnippet: JUNIT test 3.2 Introduction ... JUnit actually helps you write code faster while increasing code quality by creating synergy between coding and testing. JUnit
messageBody:
JUNIT test 3.2

Introduction
--------------

JUnit actually helps you write code faster while
increasing code quality by creating synergy between
coding and testing.

JUnit is a set of Java packages that allow one to
readily create Java test cases for Java classes, and
to then run these unit tests interactively or in batch
mode. This hopefully encourages programmers to write
unit tests for their code before they write the actual
code. The intended result is higher quality code, as
well as avoidance of the dreary task of going back and
reconstructing unit tests after all code has been
written.

By writing tests, you can quickly run the tests after
changing the code and gain confidence that your
changes didn't break anything. If a bug is detected
while running tests, the source code is fresh in your
mind, so the bug is easily found. Tests written in
JUnit help you write code at an extreme pace and spot
defects quickly

The simplest way is as an expression in a debugger.
You can change debug expressions without recompiling,
and you can wait to decide what to write until you
have seen the running objects. You can also write test
expressions as statements which print to the standard
output stream. Both styles of tests are limited
because they require human judgment to analyze their
results. Also, they don't compose nicely- you can only
execute one debug expression at a time and a program
with too many print statements causes the dreaded
"Scroll Blindness".

JUnit tests do not require human judgment to
interpret, and it is easy to run many of them at the
same time. When you need to test something, here is
what you do:

step 1 : Junit test is Available for IDE'S like
Jbuilder , Kawa , Visual Age
down load it from www.junit.org

step 2 : for doing testing on hard core JDK download
junit3.2.zip from www.xprogramming.com
or from the bellow Link

http://www.clarkware.com/articles/JUnitPrimer.html#run



step 3 : down load junit.jar a jar file with the
JUnit framework and tools
src.zip a zip file with the source code of
the junit framework
from the above link .

step 4 : unzip the junit.zip file
add junit.jar to the CLASSPATH. For example:
set classpath=%classpath%;
INSTALL_DIR\junit3\junit.jar test the installation by
using either the batch or the graphical TestRunner
tool to run the tests that come with this release. All
the tests should pass OK.
for the batch TestRunner type:
java junit.textui.TestRunner junit.samples.AllTests


step 5 : in the class path for the above include JDK
kit path also (for "javac" compiler)

step 6 : Type the program as given

import junit.framework.*;
public class MathTest extends TestCase {
protected double fValue1;
protected double fValue2;

public MathTest(String name) {
super(name);
System.out.println(" test ok ");
}

protected void setUp() {
fValue1= 2.0;
fValue2= 3.0;
}
public static void main(String arg[])
{
MathTest t = new MathTest("gan");
}
}


step 7 : compile the prog..

step 8 : Run the program

step 9: out put will be " test ok "

Eg 2 :

Why JUNIT test is required
please set the class path for
test.jar,junit.jar,src.jar

2) import test.framework.*;

16) suite.addTest(new OwnTest("hnhan")); // ***
17) return suite;
18) }
19) public void nhan()
20) {
21) String str =new String("what is ur name");
22) int k=str.length();
23) for(int j=0;j<1000000;j++)
24) {
25) for(int i=0;i<str.length();i++)
26) {
27)
28) }
29) }

30) System.out.println("nhan");
31) }

32) public static void main(String str[])
33) {
34) System.out.println("in main start");

35) test.textui.TestRunner.run(suite());
36) System.out.println("in main end");
38) }

39) }

THE ABOVE PROGRAM GIVES YOU THE FOLLOWING ERROR

in main start
.in setup
E
Time: 0.0
!!!FAILURES!!!
Test Results:
Run: 1 Failures: 0 Errors: 1
There was 1 error:
1) OwnTest.hganesh
in main end

In line 16 repalce suite.addTest(new
OwnTest("hnhan")); BY suite.addTest(new
OwnTest("nhan"));

after replacing you get the following out put

in main start
.in setup
nhan
Time: 0.60
OK (1 tests)
in main end


_______________________________________________________________________________

eg 3 :
The bellow program gives you a idea how to Test on
package's

package com.company;
public class HelloWorld {
public String sayHello() {
System.out.println("Hello World");
return "Hello World" ;
}
public static void main( String[] args ) {
HelloWorld world = new HelloWorld();
world.sayHello();
}
}

*** *** *** ***
***

++ This is the test Class

package test.com.company;
import com.company.HelloWorld;
import junit.framework.TestCase;
import junit.framework.AssertionFailedError;

public class HelloWorldTest extends TestCase {

public HelloWorldTest(String name) {
super(name);
}

public static void main(String args[]) {

junit.textui.TestRunner.run(HelloWorldTest.class);
}

public void testSayHello() {
HelloWorld world = new HelloWorld();
assert( world!=null );
assertEquals("Hello World", world.sayHello()
);
}
}

This will be the out put of the program

.Hello World
Time: 0.06
OK (1 tests)

Class Hierarchy
ï¿½ class java.lang.Object
class samples.AllTests
interface test.framework.Test
class test.framework.TestCase (implements
test.framework.Test)
class samples.TestTest
class samples.VectorTest
class samples.TestDecorator (implements
test.framework.Test)
class samples.ActiveTest
class samples.RepeatedTest
class samples.TestSetup
class test.framework.TestFailure
class test.framework.TestResult
class test.ui.UITestResult
class test.textui.TestRunner
class test.framework.TestSuite (implements
test.framework.Test)
class java.lang.Throwable (implements
java.io.Serializable)
class java.lang.Error
class test.framework.AssertionFailedError

*** note : class have bean described bellow in brief
for More information visit the bellow site


http://www.junit.org/junit/javadoc/index-all.html


AllTest is a class. It has got one method called
suite(), it return Test class Object

Test is an interface. It has got two method called
countTestCase() and run(TestResult)
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
CountTestCase() - count the number of test cases that
will be run by test.

Run(TesResult) -runs a test and collects its
result in TestResult instance

TestCase is an abstract class it extends Object and
implements Test Class.
And it has got 18 methods and one constructor.

Testcase(xxxxxx) - constructor with name as
parameter;


ASSERT :
--------

public class Assert
extends java.lang.Object
A set of assert methods.

assert(boolean)
Asserts that a condition is true.
assert(String, boolean)
Asserts that a condition is true.
assertEquals(double, double, double)
Asserts that two doubles are equal.
assertEquals(long, long)
Asserts that two longs are equal.
assertEquals(Object, Object)
Asserts that two objects are equal.
assertEquals(String, double, double, double)
Asserts that two doubles are equal.
assertEquals(String, long, long)
Asserts that two longs are equal.
assertEquals(String, Object, Object)
Asserts that two objects are equal.
countTestCases()
Counts the number of test cases executed by
run(TestResult result).
defaultResult()
Returns a default TestResult object
name()
Gets the name of the test case.
notEqualsMessage(String, Object, Object)
run()
A convenience method to run this test, collecting the
results with a default TestResult object.
run(TestResult)
Runs the test case and collects the results in
TestResult.
runTest()
Override to run the test and assert its state.
setUp()
Sets up the fixture, for example, open a network
connection.


assertEquals
--------------
public static void assertEquals(double expected,
double actual,
double delta)
Asserts that two doubles are equal.

assertEquals

public static void assertEquals(long expected,
long actual)
Asserts that two longs are equal.

assertEquals

public static void assertEquals(java.lang.Object
expected,
java.lang.Object
actual)
Asserts that two objects are equal. If they are not an
AssertionFailedError is thrown.

assertEquals
public static void assertEquals(java.lang.String
message,
double expected,
double actual,
double delta)
Asserts that two doubles are equal.

assertEquals
public static void assertEquals(java.lang.String
message,
long expected,
long actual)
Asserts that two longs are equal.

assertEquals
public static void assertEquals(java.lang.String
message,
java.lang.Object
expected,
java.lang.Object
actual)
Asserts that two objects are equal. If they are not an
AssertionFailedError is thrown.

assertNotNull
public static void assertNotNull(java.lang.Object
object)
Asserts that an object isn't null.

assertNotNull
public static void assertNotNull(java.lang.String
message,
java.lang.Object
object)
Asserts that an object isn't null.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Class TestFailure
------------------
java.lang.Object
|
+--junit.framework.TestFailure

public class TestFailure
extends java.lang.Object
A TestFailure collects a failed test together with the
caught exception

java.lang.Object
|
+--junit.framework.TestResult


public class TestResult
extends java.lang.Object

A TestResult collects the results of executing a test
case. It is an instance of the Collecting Parameter
pattern. The test framework distinguishes between
failures and errors. A failure is anticipated and
checked for with assertions. Errors are unanticipated
problems like an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException.

Its method are

countTestCases
public int countTestCases()
Counts the number of test cases that will be run by
this test.

run
public void run(TestResult result)
Runs a test and collects its result in a TestResult
instance.


-----------------------------------------------------------------------
TestSuite
----------
java.lang.Object
|
+--junit.framework.TestSuite
public class TestSuite
extends java.lang.Object
implements Test

A TestSuite is a Composite of Tests. It runs a
collection of test cases. Here is an example using the
dynamic test definition.

TestSuite suite= new TestSuite();
suite.addTest(new MathTest("testAdd"));
suite.addTest(new MathTest("testDivideByZero"));

Alternatively, a TestSuite can extract the tests to be
run automatically. To do so you pass the class of your
TestCase class to the TestSuite constructor.
TestSuite suite= new TestSuite(MathTest.class);

Its Method are :
addTest
public void addTest(Test test)

countTestCases
public int countTestCases()
Counts the number of test cases that will be run by
this test.
Specified by:
countTestCases in interface Test

run
public void run(TestResult result)
Runs the tests and collects their result in a
TestResult.
Specified by:
run in interface Test

testAt
public Test testAt(int index)
Returns the test at the given index

testCount
public int testCount()
Returns the number of tests in this suite

tests
public java.util.Enumeration tests()
Returns the tests as an enumeration

toString
public java.lang.String toString()
Overrides:
toString in class java.lang.Object
